import numpy as np # linear algebra

    for filename in filenames:
        print(os.path.join(dirname, filename))

source.b452dd94:
# Reading and understanding a single image
img = cv2.imread("../input/cusersmarildownloads24993jpeg/24993.jpeg")
plt.figure(figsize=(10,10))
plt.imshow(img, cmap = 'twilight'), plt.axis('off'), plt.title('Tokyo Olympic Games 2021',fontsize=20),plt.show()
source.6b65e7fe:
#Code by Datai https://www.kaggle.com/kanncaa1/pytorch-tutorial-for-deep-learning-lovers

# numpy array
array = [[1,2,3],[4,5,6]]
first_array = np.array(array) # 2x3 array
print("Array Type: {}".format(type(first_array))) # type
print("Array Shape: {}".format(np.shape(first_array))) # shape
print(first_array)
source.fcd038d5:
#Code by Datai https://www.kaggle.com/kanncaa1/pytorch-tutorial-for-deep-learning-lovers

# pytorch array
tensor = torch.Tensor(array)
print("Array Type: {}".format(tensor.type)) # type
print("Array Shape: {}".format(tensor.shape)) # shape
print(tensor)
source.dc4ad60a:
#Code by Datai https://www.kaggle.com/kanncaa1/pytorch-tutorial-for-deep-learning-lovers

# numpy ones
print("Numpy {}\n".format(np.ones((2,3))))

# pytorch ones
print(torch.ones((2,3)))
source.67733f4d:
#Code by Datai https://www.kaggle.com/kanncaa1/pytorch-tutorial-for-deep-learning-lovers

# numpy random
print("Numpy {}\n".format(np.random.rand(2,3)))

# pytorch random
print(torch.rand(2,3))
source.76c9258b:
#Code by Datai https://www.kaggle.com/kanncaa1/pytorch-tutorial-for-deep-learning-lovers

# create tensor 
tensor = torch.ones(3,3)
print("\n",tensor)

# Resize
print("{}{}\n".format(tensor.view(9).shape,tensor.view(9)))

# Addition
print("Addition: {}\n".format(torch.add(tensor,tensor)))

# Subtraction
print("Subtraction: {}\n".format(tensor.sub(tensor)))

# Element wise multiplication
print("Element wise multiplication: {}\n".format(torch.mul(tensor,tensor)))

# Element wise division
print("Element wise division: {}\n".format(torch.div(tensor,tensor)))

# Mean
tensor = torch.Tensor([1,2,3,4,5])
print("Mean: {}".format(tensor.mean()))

# Standart deviation (std)
print("std: {}".format(tensor.std()))

source.8d87b2ee:
Data Scientist Skills Qualifications required at the Olympic Games 2021

JOB QUALIFICATIONS - "Skills and requirements" "Exploratory data analysis using R or PYTHON. One of the languages has to be MASTERED and it is expected you have a BASIC UNDERSTANDING of THE OTHER." "Ability to work in a QUICK-PACED environment and lead regular INTERACTION with stakeholders, translating business requirements into actionable analyses. Written and verbal COMMUNICATION SKILLS around EXPLAINING data driven INSIGHTS to NON-DATA SPECIALISTS." "Demonstrated skills in collecting, aggregating, analysing, interpreting and presenting data. Proactive, ENGAGED, enthusiastic learner and willingly getting out of your comfort zone." "Experience in working with Frequentist and Bayesian (statistical) approaches, clustering techniques and MACHINE LEARNING algorithms, including but NOT LIMITED TO, linear regression, PCA, KMeans, MCMC, Random Forests and Neural Networks." "Feel comfortable in version control using Git and in CLOUD environments like AWS. FLUENT IN oral and written ENGLISH, comparable to C1 proficiency." "It is also beneficial, but not required, to have experience in:" "Experimental design, in any field, including the process of framing a problem, FORMULATING AND TESTING hypotheses. Evaluation and iteration of prediction models." "Formulating QUERIES in SQL." And interest in: "Practical applications of DEEP LEARNING techniques. Sports, Media, and the Olympic Movement." They gladly welcome candidates who DO NOT HAVE all the requirements listed above to apply to this position since they are recruiting data scientists at a range of DIFFERENT experience LEVELS. Likewise, they will ensure that successful candidates are engaged in a range of projects that are challenging and help to expand their skills." Source: https://olympicchannelservices.com/ocs_jobs/data-scientist/
